awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Removing Energy Barrier Towards Capacity-Approaching Information Transmission and Storage
awd_abstract_narration:
Project Abstract
Removing Energy Barrier towards Capacity-Approaching Information Transmission and Storage
The objective of this research is to cut the total energy of achieving near Shannon capacity information transmission and storage. While it is common to use channel coding to save transmit energy for a reliable delivery, the decode energy of some of the best capacity-approaching codes can be prohibitive due to circuit complexities and overtake transmit energy. Many capacity-approaching codes are not guaranteed to work well either, as they often give up their effectiveness at low error rates, requiring extra transmit energy to maintain their performance. The rising energy for both transmit and decode poses obstacles to future high-performance applications, such as optical and wireline communications, due to the escalating cost of operating closer to the ultimate channel capacity. More severe impediments are placed on low-energy applications, such as battery-powered portable devices and sensors, in their path of acquiring more robust communication and storage capabilities.
This research advances state-of-the-art coding algorithms and techniques by addressing two research frontiers of near-capacity low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes: (1) the intrinsic weakness of LDPC codes that is manifested as error floors; and (2) the high decode energy due to interconnection complexity and memory inefficiency. The approaches span coding theory and integrated circuits, and their novelties are threefold: (1) creation of a universal, low-cost local search algorithm to overcome error floors; (2) creation of transient memory to exploit data access pattern for low energy; and (3) new techniques to improve the achievable performance of non-binary LDPC codes while reducing interconnection complexity. This project trains students in both coding theory and integrated circuits and draws broad participation of students, professional colleagues, and industrial partners in collaborative research and education.

por.por_cntn:
This research project aims at reducing the total energy of achieving efficient, near Shannon capacity information transmission and storage through channel coding. The total energy includes both transmit energy and decode energy.

Towards this goal, the project created state-of-the-art energy-efficient LDPC, nonbinary LDPC and polar decoder designs using new algorithm-circuits co-design techniques, including transient embedded memories, dynamic convergence detection, fine-grained clock gating, and bit-splitting register files. Over the course of the project, we demonstrated five prototype channel coding IC chips, including the most energy efficient LDPC decoder chip (at the time of publication), the first nonbinary LDPC decoder chip, the first nonbinary LDPC-based iterative detection-decoding multiple-input multiple-output wireless receiver chip, the first belief propagation polar decoder chip, and the first configurable belief propagation polar decoder chip.

The project created new decoding algorithms, including post-processing algorithms to improve the error-correcting performance of LDPC codes, and algorithm to construct polar codes to achieve the optimal error-correcting performance.

The project contributed new tools and methods for the evaluation of channel codes and decoders. A configurable platform and an automated design flow were established to simplify the design of LDPC and polar decoders on FPGA for performance evaluation.

Five graduate students (including one female student) and six undergraduate students (including four female students) participated in this research. Students were trained in both coding theory and integrated circuits. The research has produced two Ph.D. graduates and one M.S. graduate. A new advanced graduate class was established in 2011 and offered twice at the University of Michigan. Part of this class was based on this research project. Six internship projects were created in collaboration with Texas Instruments, Broadcom, Marvell, and Intel to train graduate students and help transfer technology to industry. This research has encouraged women to pursue careers in research. After participating in this research, all four undergraduate female students have continued to pursue graduate schools.
